comment: He is inconsistent with discussion posts and instructions. The grading is extremely harsh. He wanted us to buy a textbook only for us to use it as inspiration for one discussion post. By far the worst teacher I've had in my 3 years of college. He is clearly new at teaching and it shows. SAVE YOURSELF. DO NOT TAKE HIS CLASS.

I did not enjoy this class as much as I should have. Classmates were awesome which made it bearable. Instructor was very blunt, critical and comes across as condescending and arrogant. Often was contradictory with instructions for projects. Most days I left class very frustrated and felt a sense of dread. Never felt like that about a class.

Appears to be new at teaching. Has made me cry on several occasions. Grades way too harshly for hard work. Alex is very off putting and tries to be relatable but doesn't. Tends to put students down by what he says. Says derogatory and insensitive comments. Rarely says anything positive about work. Seems to expects us to already know material.

The course content was interesting. Enjoyed learning new concepts and applications. Often times Alex would make remarks that were condescending. Rarely gave any positive feedback or encouragement. Maybe he meant well but he needs to work on his delivery. Projects are very confusing. Rarely responds to emails. Take this course with someone else.

My experience will probably be different because we had covid-19 schedules when I took Alex's class. His lectures and projects were fun, but he was very blunt during critiques. We did have to buy a textbook for a small assignment, and didn't open it after that. His class was not hard but it was stressful.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Every time he looks at our works he gives backhanded compliments. His feedback is very hard to take seriously because it felt like he was talking down to us. The class is great but his lectures are sometimes hard to follow and he doesnt help much with questions about programs and he has told us to just google something even though hes teaching us
I enjoyed the projects and learning the basics of art applications. Instructor provided feedback which was constructive. Didn't connect with instructor. He's a bit off putting.

Teaches better in person. Weekly discussion posts. Takes a while to reply emails. We made a portrait, character design, imagined landscape, print a portfolio, and learned Illustrator, PS, & InDesign. We had to get a Phaidon art book which was unnecessary. His critiques are helpful, but some I wouldn't take to heart. Tries to make content fun.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Graded by few things--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: The highlights: Offers plenty of feedback (is available if you ask for/need more clarity), everything you're graded on is clearly laid out, and there was a bonus extra credit paper that is super easy. Things to look out for: You gotta show up to class + pay attention, there's no traditional textbook so take notes if you don't have a great memory.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Alex is cool, but taking his class you can tell that his passion is for photography. He makes lots of jokes and likes works that are strange and outside of the box. Follow his project syllabus word for word and you shouldnt have any issues. His feedback can be vague and confusing sometimes. It was easy enough to make an A in his class.

Dont take Prof. Alex if you cry easily. He often makes remarks and comments that are either derogatory or rub the wrong way. He has repeatedly misgendered students and makes comments in an attempt to be relatable but dont hit. During critique he will often degrade and make unnecessary comments that are hurtful. Beware

Instructor appears to be new at teaching. Lacks the ability to relate to his students. Often makes disrespectful and derogatory comments that are hurtful. He tries to be cool but not. Projects are confusing. Never had a class that I dreaded like this one. It's not the class itself but being in his presence.
